utterances: Well, I think it's - a lot of people don't agree with me, but I think it's negative messaging.
If you say to somebody, just take one bite, I think the implication is that they shouldn't take a second bite.
So I think if you say, wow, this is fantastic, that's just a better message.
You're also a big proponent, Sally, of shopping and cooking together with kids, getting them really involved in the process so they have some ownership of it, really.
Harrison believes that maybe the company got bit by karma.
In the 1990s, independent coffee houses worried that the proliferation of Starbucks would shut them out.
It turns out the new Starbucks were mostly competing with themselves.
In the end, the only victim was the Starbucks brand.
Robert Smith, NPR News, New York.
Right now in Crawford, Texas, we're about to see the closest thing we get to a royal wedding.
Okay.
Maybe see is not the right word.
First Daughter Jenna Bush is getting hitched, and there's a veil of secrecy over the festivities that would make the CIA proud.
The Washington Post's Amy Argetsinger has been trying to get the scoop, and she joins us now from Crawford.
And, Amy, how far are you from the altar?
I think roughly between 12 and 15 miles away.
I don't know exactly where the ranch is.
This is my first time to Crawford and they're not exactly (unintelligible) for us to find the place.
Are you in the high school gym?
I am in the high school gym right now, yes.
We just had a wonderful catered lunch and we're just waiting for stuff to happen.
It's the standard filing center when the press goes down to cover Bush, but I don't think Americans know that Crawford is more or less a crossroads with a water tower.
Yes.
I think there are also some grain elevators and there's a swimming hole.

There are a couple of a souvenir stands where you can get talking president dolls, a lot of Bush T-shirts, a lot of Bush buttons and, you know, of course, this week a lot of the Jenna and Henry souvenirs.
Cool.
Like what?
Well, there's the Jenna and Henry mouse pad.
I bought the last one of those.
There's the...
(Soundbite of laughter)
...Jenna and Henry hand-tooled leather coaster.
I also bought the last one of those.
A lot of mugs, a lot of buttons, framed photos, things like that.
Of course, you know, the souvenir stands are sort of in the same boat we're in.
We don't have a lot of information.
They don't have a lot of pictures.
So, every Jenna and Henry souvenir has the same photo of them that was released when they got engaged last year, and you see that same photo staring out at you from every single store window here.
So, is this the kind of thing you'll be writing about for the style section?
I mean, you're not going to even get to see the dress or the cake of the first dance.
What do you write?
Reporters are here going out on the street talking to the owners of the souvenir stand, talking to the tourists.
Every time a press secretary shows up here in the filing center, we berate and beg and wheedle and plead for something, something.
(Soundbite of laughter)
What are you wearing, Amy, to the wedding?
Or rather...
(Soundbite of laughter)
...the wedding coverage?
I'm wearing a polo shirt and some long pants so that I don't get sunburned.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Not exactly...
It's freezing in this gymnasium so I've got a sweater, believe it or not.
Not exactly Vera Wang, huh?
Not exactly Vera Wang.
Well, you know, this day isn't really about me.
It's about Jenna.
Amy Argetsinger of the Washington Post from Crawford, Texas, waiting with bated breath for tonight's Jenna Bush/Henry Hager wedding.
Have fun down there.
Thank you very much.
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
And I'm Susan Stamberg in for Renee Montagne.
It is day two of forced evacuation of Jewish settlements in Gaza and parts of the West Bank.
Troops have been removing protesters from two synagogues in the settlements of Neve Dekalim and Kfar Darom.
Yesterday, a settler killed four Palestinian laborers in a shooting rampage on the West Bank.
Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon denounced that attack as a twisted act of Jewish terror.
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas is urging his people to avoid violence.
But militant factions continue to claim victory for this Israeli pullout.
NPR's Peter Kenyon reports from Gaza City.
(Soundbite of marching band)
In Gaza City's Sheikh Radwan neighborhood, the small left wing militant faction known as the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine staged a military show.
Boys and young men dressed in green camouflage and black face masks chanted and marched in place in an empty lot.
It was hardly precision marching and many of the rockets on their shoulders were fakes.
But an effigy of a Jewish settlement was burned and the message was clear.
This group wants to keep up the armed resistance in the West Bank now that Gaza is being liberated.

The FLP central committee member, Kaihad Ahul(ph), says the Israeli pullout was due to the martyrs, the gunmen and bombers who attacked Israelis for nearly the past five years and not, he says, to any diplomatic efforts by President Mahmoud Abbas and the Palestinian Authority.
(Through Translator) The Gaza withdrawal didn't take place as a result of the negotiations.
It was a unilateral action and it's aimed to boost the occupation in the West Bank and to cut an attempt of negotiations with the Palestinians.
If you could take a drug that might help you think better or perform more effectively and efficiently in school or at work, would you do it?
And if so, do you think that's the same as taking a drug that helps you hit more homeruns?
That's one of the questions being raised in the debate over brain-enhancement drugs.

Once prescribed mainly for people with disabilities, brain-enhancement drugs are now being used more frequently by students who are about to take a tough test or by academics and other professionals who may be getting ready for a big presentation.
Is it cheating or not?
The reality is that the NAACP's past CEO left unexpectedly, missed several fundraising initiatives that sort of stopped at the time and have to be regenerated.
And he left at the time that we didn't have a chief fundraiser.
Had he stayed, it's speculative as to whether we would have met the revenue projections for the year.
But it's also true that for the past several years, the NAACP has missed its revenue projections.
And we've decided that we won't draw down on our reserves unless absolutely necessary.
So there, it sounds like Hayes is basically saying it's Gordon's fault.
And Gordon told The Baltimore Sun that the NAACP's board, which you lead, is the fault.
So how do you break it down?
Well, there are 64 people on the board.
Are the 64 people wrong or is the one person who quit the half-wrong?
I don't want to get into a back and forth with Bruce Gordon.
Both of us, I think, have said far too much about his departure.
But the fact is that if any organization precipitously leaves - or loses its top official, then there's some moments of turmoil within the organization.
And we certainly experienced some measures of turmoil.
But we're on the road to recovery.
We're - got our fundraising apparatus in place.
And I feel quite confident that within, not the immediate future, but say, six to nine months, we'll be back on solid ground once again.
What's the average age of your members?
I have no idea.
But I will tell you this that young people, and that's high school and college age, are the fastest growing segments of our membership.
If there is any lack in up and down the age ladder, it's not kids, it's not college students, it's people in the say, 35 to 45 or 25 to 45-year-old range.
But that's true of so many volunteer organizations.
Apparently, the school heart is building jobs, building homes and families, engaged in personal efforts that doesn't leave them - don't leave them much time for volunteer organizations like ours.
We know when they get to hit 45, they'll come back to us.
Do you have time though - do you have time to get those people into the folds?
You've got your 100th anniversary coming up in a couple of years.
You are having these financial decision-making issues that you have to make.
I presume that there's some way to attract people in that age group.
What are you going to do about it?
Well, we're trying every way we can.
We, for the last several years, had an exercise we call Leadership 500 where we invite people in this age group, who are not affiliated with the NAACP, to spend the week in learning about us.
We're going to continue that.
We're growing our youth chapters, our high school chapters, these are people whom we hope will continue on with the NAACP as they get older, and some of them do.
But we're like the church.
You go into a church today.
You see a lot of kids.
You see a lot of older people.
You don't see that important middle core and we, like the church and other organizations, are desperate to get a hold of them.
If you had to describe the NAACP as a person who had gone through various stages of development and tackled various issues, where would the NAACP be now?
You have, you know, if you say that it's a person, you have someone who was a freedom fighter, a justice leader, what now is that body trying to do?
I thought you were going to ask me to mention a name of some person of the NAACP was like, it's just like a Barbara Walter's interview.
But I know, I think we'd be calling ourselves a freedom fighter.

We call ourselves someone who is tried and true, who's won many, many victories in the past, who will win other victories in the future, who needs help from every American in the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
We think colored people come in all colors.
And anybody who shares our values is more than welcome.
All they've got to do is go to NAACP.com - dot-org - I'm sorry - NAACP.org on the Internet and join up.
Finally, very briefly, how long do you plan to stay in your position?
Well, NAACP chairs have one-year terms.
I'm in my 9th term.
I'd very much like to be here when we celebrate our centennial in 2009 but that's up to the electorate, my board of directors, but I'm going to ask them to send me back a couple of more times.
